entry.title: Carenado Releases Beechcraft Baron B55 for MSFS 2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Carenado has released its Beechcraft Baron B55 for MSFS 2024, available exclusively through the in-sim Marketplace. The light twin-engine aircraft arrives as the latest addition to the developerâs growing MSFS 2024 catalogue. The Baron B55 is a light twin, first introduced in 1961, as part of Beechcraftâs Baron family, which evolved from the earlier Travel Air. Production of the 55 series continued until 1983, with 3,651 units built. Powered by two Continental IO-470-L engines, producing 260 horsepower each, the aircraft is capable of cruising at around 190 knots, with a range of more than 900 nautical miles. Its six-seat layout and twin-engine configuration made it a popular choice for both private and training operations. The package also features eight liveries, plus a paint kit, and an EFB with 2024 interfacing, for switching between avionics configurations. Additional systems modelled include a Garmin GMA 340 audio panel, Garmin GTX 330 transponder, weather radar, and fuel flow indicators. The aircraft is also compatible with MSFS 2024âs Career mode out of the box, with support for missions such as ferry flights and charter services. entry.title: Miltech & Blackbird Update MH-60 for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Miltech and Blackbird Simulations have recently released version 1.0.2 of their MH-60 Multi-Mission Helicopter add-on for MSFS 2020 and 2024, bringing a series of improvements, optimisations, and fixes. The new version introduces a further reworked flight model, aiming to improve overall manoeuvrability, hover control, and responsiveness across pitch, roll, and yaw inputs. Rotor animations and blade coning have also been refined. Optimised textures and further compression have improved VRAM usage by about 1 gigabyte, and mipmapping has been added for further scalability across different hardware. Autopilot and hover mode control logic have been revised for improved stability, alongside more accurate vertical speed control. Version 1.0.2 also includes new keybinds for hover adjustments, as well as clickable rotor brake and search light controls. Visual enhancements such as dynamic dirt, mud, and insect accumulation were also added. According to the changelog, the release resolves more than 40 issues, ranging from livery errors and animation bugs to lighting, radio, and crew call. Specific fixes include adjustments to the APU, tail fold, and pitot cover textures. Several regressions in textures were also addressed. Miltech noted that users who previously installed the low-VRAM patch of the MH-60 should first test the new version 1.0.2 without it, as memory optimisation has been significantly improved in this update. A patch will still be available for those requiring additional performance adjustments. The developers also confirmed ongoing work on Mission Hub, with further improvements, bug fixes, and new features expected soon. Testing is also underway for an Xbox release of both the MH-60 and Mission Hub, with version 1.0.2 set as the release build. The full changelog follows below: â¢ FIXED: Various issues with APU Start (sound looping, fuel starvation, switching on/off)â¢ FIXED: When starting "Ready to Fly", PCLs are now on DIR, and UTIL PUMP is Off.â¢ FIXED: Prime Fuel Pump starving the APU from fuel fixed.â¢ FIXED: Incorrect "Rotor Brake" indication on MD removed.â¢ FIXED: Tail Fold not working correctly on FS24 fixed.â¢ FIXED: Weapon Release cover not hiding with cyclic fixed.â¢ FIXED: AO Shadow on the front panel, Romeo and Tango, fixed.â¢ FIXED: Regression on the Pitot Cover texture fixed.â¢ FIXED: Various regressions on textures fixed.â¢ IMPROVED: Increased Compression Quality on selected external texture COMP Maps [FS20]â¢ IMPROVED: Adjusted Compression Quality on selected textures to lower VRAM consumption. Added mipmapping and removed conditions that made textures not scalable with MSFS Sliders [FS24]â¢ IMPROVED: Various improvements and adjustments to the HOVER Mode PID controller.â¢ IMPROVED: Blade rigidity and coning readjusted. You can read the full update post on Miltech Simulations' Facebook page. The MH-60 is available for $37.99, via the Miltech Simulations, Blackbird Simulations and iniBuilds stores. entry.title: AG Sim Releases El Hierro Airport for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. AG Sim has just released its version of El Hierro Airport (GCHI) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024. Located on the island of El Hierro, part of the Canary Islands, the airport welcomes nearly 270,000 passengers annually. The airport first opened its doors in 1972 with the goal of serving national air traffic for both passengers and cargo. Between 1989 and 1990, the old control tower was demolished, and a new one was constructed alongside a new passenger terminal. A few years later, the runway was extended, allowing the airport to accommodate larger aircraft. Today, the airport is served by two airlines: Binter Canarias and CanaryFly, which operate flights to Gran Canaria and Tenerife-North. The newly released scenery features detailed 3D buildings, terminal interiors, 8K PBR textures, a 2025 layout, precise terraforming and slopes, and much more. entry.title: Microsoft Releases Sim Update 3 for MSFS 2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Microsoft has recently released the highly anticipated Sim Update 3 for MSFS 2024, marking one of the biggest updates to the simulator since launch. It brings performance fixes, weather and world upgrades, aircraft, traffic, and ATC changes, airport improvements, SDK updates, and broad adjustments to core systems, and career mode. Labelled version 1.5.27.0, SU3 brings wide-ranging changes, including the highly requested ability to locally download content from the MSFS Library. This allows more control over content management, with simulator files being able to be stored locally on a userâs system, rather than relying solely on cloud-based streaming and internet downloads. Fixes to weather include an issue where the correct METAR data was not always honoured at airports; furthermore, lightning in storms is now far less excessive, thunderstorm prediction is better, and cloud transitions on the world map are smoother. Distant cloud lighting has been improved, photogrammetry tile popping is reduced, and map camera zooming has been corrected. Streaming reliability should be better, including fixes for freezes caused by mislabelled sound folders. AI and live traffic now flow more smoothly, with fewer overshoots, ârear-end incidentsâ, and stuck vehicles. Taxi speeds have been tuned, parked aircraft distribution rebalanced, and model-matching now prefers AI-optimised assets. Contrails rendering has been improved, gear animations have been corrected, livery depiction improved, and generic placeholder aircraft have been phased out. Aircraft across the default fleet have received updates, with refinements to Garmin avionics and autopilot systems. The Boeing 787, 747, and Airbus A320neo have seen flight dynamics and stability tweaks, while the Cessna 172 and Daher TBM 930 have received various bug fixes and performance improvements. Significant performance and stability upgrades have also been introduced. Sim Update 3 includes better memory management, improved CPU and GPU balancing, and reduced stuttering, during heavy scenery loading. Smoother framerates should be noticable in high-density areas, such as large international airports, and photogrammetry-heavy cities.Â Some of the addressed issues include Xbox boot crashes when many packages are installed, several rare parser and stallâwarning crashes, VR in/out switching, airportârendering freezes, and texture handling that could corrupt WASM gauges, on Series S, or lowâtexture settings on PC. Menu caching in Controls now reduces unnecessary file I/O, and avatar thumbnails are generated faster. DLSS MultiâFrame Generation options have been corrected, and multiple content management edge cases have been cleaned up, in order to prevent profile or content conflicts. Sim Update 3 is available now on all platforms, as a free download for all MSFS 2024 users. Full patch notes can be found on the official Microsoft Flight Simulator website, and the MSFS forums. entry.title: Microsoft Releases Eurocopter EC 135 for MSFS 2024 Free of Charge
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Microsoft has just released the Eurocopter EC 135 for free, alongside Sim Update 3, which was also released earlier today.Â The Eurocopter EC135 is an advanced light twin-engine utility helicopter that can seat up to eight passengers, produced by Airbus Helicopters, previously named Eurocopter. This is Microsoftâs 21st âLocal Legendâ, and is the last of the four free aircraft promised by Microsoft to make up for MSFS 2024âs launch problems.Â The Eurocopter has a rich history, originating from a collaboration between Messerschmitt-BÃ¶lkow-Blohm (MBB) and Aerospatiale in the 1970s. The EC 135 introduced innovative technologies such as full-authority digital engine controls (FADEC) for helicopters and a hingeless main rotor. The company that developed the EC 135 has undergone significant changes over the years. Originally known as MBB, it was acquired by Daimler-Benz and subsequently merged into DASA. In 1992, DASA joined forces with Aerospatiale to become Eurocopter, which was later rebranded as Airbus Helicopters in 2014. Because of the 2014 rebranding, what was previously the Eurocopter EC 135 is today branded as the Airbus Helicopters H135. entry.title: SimWorks Studios Releases GA-8 Airvan for MSFS 2020
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS20. SimWorks Studios has released the GA-8 Airvan for MSFS 2020, bringing one of Australiaâs most versatile general aviation aircraft into the sim, with an MSFS 2024 release to follow. The Airvan has been developed with a strong focus on realism. You can choose between cargo and passenger layouts, with or without the cargo pod. The aircraft features a highly detailed 3D model, sounds recorded from a real GA-8, and a custom flight model, verified by pilots of the type. Dynamic wear and tear is included, where dirt and mud can accumulate over flight hours. These visual details persist between flights, and even rain can wash the aircraft clean again. A tablet EFB is included, giving access to loading options, checklists, avionics hot-swapping between GTN750Xi, GTN750, and GNS530/430, as well as access to various aircraft settings. Manuals and configuration tools are built directly into the tablet, keeping everything accessible from the cockpit. This release also marks the debut of SystemsPulse, SimWorks Studiosâ new technology, designed to simulate deeper aircraft behaviour. Available in the SystemsPulse Edition of the Airvan, sold separately, the expansion introduces over 70 failure scenarios that may occur randomly, progressively with use, or at the pilotâs command. Covering areas such as engine performance, electrical systems, and operational wear, SystemsPulse gives additional incentive to manage the aircraft properly, as if you were its real-world operator. Both editions come with an official paint kit and a PDF manual. Six liveries are provided across pod and non-pod variants, including base white, Stichting Hoogvliegers, Nissos Kos, VortX, Yellow, and Safari Wings. Customers who purchase the MSFS 2020 version of the GA-8 Airvan now will also receive the MSFS 2024 edition, at no extra cost, upon release. The GA-8 Airvan is available now on the MSFS Marketplace for $29.99, with the optional SystemsPulse expansion sold separately for $17.49. A future release is planned for the SimWorks Studios store.
